article.title: Life never goes as planned. And that's ok

text.paragraph: One nice spring Saturday, I had everything organized for a hike on the border trails towards Mount Saddle. I had planned all the tough climbs and vantage points, and read all the trail maps to optimize my day and my training. I wanted to cover a long distance for a day hike, 25km so I couldn't do this without a good plan. So everything had to be fine, or should have.

After a few hours of walking, I finally start to gain altitude and reach a point of view. However, what I see does not correspond to my research on the route. I wonder without worrying yet, and luckily, crosses paths with two hunters. One of them asks me where I'm going like this, to which I answer: Mount Saddle. Their eyes meet before pointing me away:- Mount Saddle is the little blue spot that you can see on the horizon. It's a very long distance, I hope you know what you're getting into!- I thank him with a nervous little laugh, and continue my journey (ah, damn attitude of never giving up).

So let's do the topo. At the start of the trail I took the wrong section only to realize far too late that I had embarked on a detour of an additional 10 km. On a very hot and sunny day, and given the level of difficulty of the trail, I was starting to worry a bit about the risk of dehydration.

At the time, I was really disappointed with myself and felt bitterness, because I really wanted this day as I had planned it. And that's when I remembered a quote from one of my favorite author-explorers: `` It is rare on a trip to live days in accordance with the ideas that we had forged before the great departures. ''
